div1.p: This memorandum contains Manuel Perez Beato's translated responses concerning Camp Columbia.

div1.head: Memorandum from [John J. Moran?] to [Philip S. Hench], October 16, 1940
div1.p:
Answers of Dr. Manuel Perez Beato to your letter of August 25th.
(Delivered to me in written form in Spanish. The translation
follows) (Sra. Maria, Vda. de Projas brought them to the office)
1. Camp Columbia was made up of tents during the Intervention.
Previously, the land was unoccupied. There was nothing on it.
2. The wooden barracks were begun during the time of General
Wood.
3. Masonry houses were built for officers in 1926 and Military
City constructed in 1935.
4. He does not know of any written history of Camp Columbia.
5. There is a history of Las Animas Hospital by Enrique
Barnet. The Finlay Institute Library has it.
6. He has some old maps of Marianao.
7. He sent you copy of the photographs which he has of
Camp Columbia. He would need time to look for the photographs of
the other places.
9. The Hospital No. 1 was called Alfonso XII. It was located
at the back of Calixto Garcia Hospital toward the West. There are
still some wooden pavilions of the old Hospital.

The above information is from memory but if he has time before
you need the data he will look among his papers and perhaps can
find more interesting information to offer you, and perhaps photo-
graphs of Hospital No. 1.

Referring to the statements which he made that night in his
house concerning Dr. Finlay, these were confidential and he prefers
that you do not mention anything about same.
